Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 40096 
July 2006 
 
 
 
 
Statistical Capacity Building 
in the Asia and Pacific Region 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  CSP  –  country strategy and program 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  MDG  –  Millennium Development Goal  
  MfDR  –  Managing for Development Results 
  NSS  –  national statistical system  
  RD  –  regional department 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  SCB  –  statistical capacity building 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management, and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Governance, capacity development  
Subtheme  –  Public governance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
Vice President  G. H. P. B. Van Der Linden, Knowledge Management and 
Sustainable Development  
Chief Economist  I. Ali, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
Assistant Chief Economist  B. D. Pant, Development Indicators and Policy Research Division, 
ERD 
   
Team leaders  A. Asra, Senior Statistician, ERD 
B. Sim, Statistician, ERD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Statistical systems in the Asia and Pacific region urgently need to be developed and 
modernized. The timely availability of reliable statistical data is increasingly important to the 
development  communities,  particularly  with  the  adoption  of  Millennium  Development  Goals 
(MDGs) and the Managing for Development Results (MfDR) approach. Without such data,  
MDG and MfDR results and impact cannot be monitored. However, for various reasons, national 
statistical systems (NSSs) in most developing member countries (DMCs) often cannot produce 
the needed data on time. Although the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has long experience in 
statistical capacity building (SCB), a more systematic approach to SCB and to the monitoring of 
the implementation of SCB technical assistance (TA) is still needed, in line with ADB’s more 
systematic approach to its other activities. 
 
2.  On  16  January  2006  an  Economics  and  Research  Department  (ERD)  paper  titled 
Statistical Capacity Building in the Asian and Pacific Region,1 presenting the new approach to 
SCB, was approved by the President. It marked a move from an ad hoc to a systems approach 
to providing statistical assistance. ADB assistance will henceforth focus on building the capacity 
of the statistically very weak DMCs under a long-term program.2 SCB will be integrated into the 
country  and  strategy  program  (CSP)  and  will  be  designed  and  implemented  with  the  full 
ownership of both DMCs and regional departments (RDs)3 and with technical support from 
ERD.4 To  implement  the  new  SCB  approach,  a  regional  technical  assistance  (RETA)  is 
proposed to assess the statistical capacity, constraints, and needs of DMCs; to identify DMCs 
that are statistically very weak; and to develop separate long-term SCB TA programs for those 
DMCs.5  The RETA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The current approach to SCB TA does not involve a systematic review of the need for an 
SCB TA program in a DMC and its relevance to the DMC’s own statistical development strategy. 
Nor does it involve an assessment of whether an SCB TA request from a DMC matches ADB’s 
own priority goals for statistical development in the region. 
 
4.  In the past, the selection of SCB TA programs was based on ad hoc requests made by 
individual  DMCs  through  the  RDs  rather  than  on  systematic  strategic  considerations.  The 
programs were implemented piecemeal and were not systematically monitored. In providing 
SCB  TA  to  the  statistically  very  weak  DMCs  in  future,  ADB  must  consider  how  these 
shortcomings can be overcome. One option would be to consider the prospects for success of 
those DMCs’ statistical systems, since the TA can provide much-needed help but cannot by 
itself determine the success or failure of the system. For this, however, the prospects for 
success, country by country, must be systematically evaluated.  
 
5.  In the experience of ERD, common obstacles to statistical development are (i) lack of 
political will, (ii) lack of transparency, (iii) chronic budgetary insufficiency for routine statistical 
activities, and (iv) high staff turnover, undermining the effectiveness of training. The long-term 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2006. Statistical Capacity Building in the Asian and Pacific Region. Manila. 
2  Statistically very weak DMCs also tend to be weakly performing DMCs. 
3  In this paper, RDs include resident missions. 
4  The project administration will be handled by the RDs, while ERD will play a major role in the technical aspects of 
the TA, including the recruitment of consultants, and participation in inception, review, and technical consultations 
missions as needed. 
5  The RETA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 14 March 2006.

2   
SCB TA program must address these obstacles if the TA is to be successful. A major deciding 
factor in providing an SCB TA program is the commitment shown by a statistically very weak 
DMC to develop its NSS, including the allocation of a sufficient budget for sustained statistical 
activities.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  This RETA is aimed at assisting selected statistically very weak DMCs in providing more 
accurate, relevant, and timely statistical information by developing long-term SCB TA programs 
that are agreed upon by RDs and these DMCs. The RETA will have two major outputs, namely, 
diagnostic studies and draft long-term SCB TA programs for the selected statistically very weak 
DMCs, which will be the basis for statistical development in these countries. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The RETA outputs will be obtained through a combination of (i) consulting services, 
(ii) country  consultations,  (iii)  support  for  data  collection,  (iv)  processing,  (v)  analysis,  and 
(vi) dissemination.  The  RETA  will  be  implemented  in  two  phases.  Phase  1  will  lay  the 
groundwork  by  (i)  pulling  together  and  synthesizing  available  studies  and  information, 
(ii) identifying criteria to determine the statistically very weak DMCs, and (iii) collecting basic 
information. In this first phase, 13 DMCs will be reviewed: Afghanistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, 
Bangladesh, Bhutan, Kyrgyz Republic, Maldives, Mongolia, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Tajikistan, Timor-
Leste, and Viet Nam.6 The choice of the 13 DMCs was based on (i) cost considerations, (ii) 
eligibility for Asian Development Fund (ADF) grants, (iii) existence of an ADB TA/RETA on SCB, 
(iv) likelihood that these DMCs are statistically very weak given the low availability of relevant 
data in these countries, and (v) the frameworks used by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) 
in certifying the adequacy of published statistical data in various countries for the needs of data 
users.7   
 
8.  Phase 1 will have three key activities: (i) assessing the level of statistical development of 
the 13 DMCs, (ii) identifying statistically very weak DMCs from among the 13 DMCs and 
selecting candidates for SCB TA projects, and (iii) conducting diagnostic studies for the selected 
statistically  very  weak  DMCs.  Phase  2  will  have  two  key  activities,  namely  (i)  developing 
separate long-term SCB TA programs for the statistically very weak DMCs that are selected for 
SCB TA projects, on the basis of their national strategy for the development of statistics, in 
phase 1; and (ii) preparing a monitoring template for each selected statistically very weak DMC.8    
 
                                                 
6  Six of the 13 DMCs are poor, debt stressed, or post-conflict DMCs that are among those listed in ADB. 2004. The 
ADF IX Grants Program: Staff Instructions. Compendium of Staff Instructions (approved by the President on 23 
November). Available: Lotus Notes database, LNADBG1. 
7  The two frameworks are the General Data Dissemination Standard (GDDS) and the Special Data Dissemination 
Standard (SDDS). The GDDS involves a basic level of data availability, while SDDS involves a higher level of 
availability. Of the 13 DMCs covered by the RETA, eight already participate in the GDDS, two (Armenia and Kyrgyz 
Republic) subscribe to SDDS, and three (Bhutan, Maldives, and Timor-Leste) have not subscribed to either GDDS 
or SDDS.  
8  Many DMCs have either prepared or are preparing a national strategy for development statistics in response to the 
call in the Marrakech Action Plan for Statistics for the implementation of such strategies in every low-income 
country by 2006. The availability of these strategies in DMCs will therefore provide a good basis for ADB 
involvement in SCB.

3
9.  To minimize the risk of failure in implementing an SCB TA program, ADB will consider a 
portfolio approach in giving SCB TA to the selected statistically weak DMCs. This would involve 
(i)  giving  more  assistance  to  countries  with  stronger  prospects  for  a  successful  outcome, 
(ii) setting  clear  conditionalities  for  countries  where  the  prospect  for  a  successful  outcome 
appears doubtful, and (iii) monitoring compliance with the conditionalities. 
 
  1.  Phase 1 
 
  a.  Assess DMCs’ Level of Statistical Development 
10.  The study will assess the 13 DMCs’ level of statistical development and capacity,9 and 
identify DMCs that are considered statistically very weak on the basis of a number of criteria, 
such  as  availability  of  priority  indicators,  existing  statistical  capacity,10 and  availability  of 
standard skills.11 The study will also take into account scoring systems developed by other 
agencies for evaluating the level of statistical development of a country. The assessment will be 
carried out in two stages. First, a desk study will clarify the concept of “statistically very weak 
DMCs” and classify most cases on the basis of information already available at ADB. The desk 
study will take into account data available from ERD archives and on Internet sites such as 
those of the IMF, World Bank (WB), United Nations (UN) agencies, and PARIS21.12 Second, 
further information will be collected for DMCs that are borderline statistically very weak. This 
information would be collected through e-mail, phone calls, or field visits, if necessary. During 
the desk study and field visits, attempts will also be made to (i) identify the factors that are 
conducive  to  progress and  those  that  hinder it,  (ii)  previous  and  planned  assistance  from 
funding agencies, and (iii) any known gaps in data and problems with data quality.  
 
  b.  Identify Statistically Very Weak DMCs and Select Candidates 
  for SCB TA Projects 
11.  Considering other factors, including assistance already being provided by other funding 
agencies, ERD, in consultation with RDs, will select candidates for SCB TA projects from 
among the statistically very weak DMCs. Countries where other funding agencies are not yet 
heavily involved will be given preference. A set of principles for dealing with the most common 
obstacles to statistical progress will be proposed. 
 
c.  Conduct  a  Diagnostic  Study  for  Each  Selected  Statistically  Very 
Weak DMC 
12.  For  the  countries  that  are  identified  as  candidates  for  SCB  TA  projects,  national 
consultants, with inputs from the DMCs concerned, will study existing statistical activities in 
depth, identify major gaps in data, and determine the extent of demand for existing statistics and

the types of data now collected by government agencies outside the national statistical office. 
The study will identify factors that hinder or promote the development of statistics, and assess 
the availability of an adequate budget for statistical development, human resources, information 
technology equipment, and surveys. If necessary, the diagnostic study will also recommend the 
introduction of conditionalities in the proposed SCB TA project. 
 
2.  Phase 2  
 
  a.  Develop  a  Long-Term  SCB  TA  Program  for  Each  Selected 
  Statistically Very Weak DMC 
 
13.  For each selected statistically very weak DMC, a long-term SCB TA program13 that is 
considered  most  suitable  for  ADB  involvement  will  be  developed.  It  will  be  based  on  the 
diagnostic study in phase 1 and close consultations with the RD and DMC concerned. The long-
term statistical program will address issues such as the availability of a statistical legislative 
framework, management and organization of the statistical system, level of budgetary resources 
available for statistical activities, lack of demand for existing data, and incorporation of data 
collected by nonstatistical government agencies into the NSS. Depending on the needs of these 
DMCs, the TA will address, among others, the priority concerns of ADB, including the likelihood 
of success in preparing time-series data for selected indicators and the need for ADB to avoid 
dispersing its SCB efforts in too many directions. Dealing with such concerns will provide a 
basis for constructing a monitoring template.  
 
14.  ADB will explore various sources of financing, including loans, and the possibility of 
creating a statistical capacity building trust fund for the SCB TA programs that are developed. At 
the same time, to ensure effective SCB TA implementation and the long-term sustainability of 
the SCB TA activities beyond the life of the SCB TA, the SCB TA programs should include 
appropriate conditionalities. These would include the release of funds only after the selected 
statistically very weak DMC concerned has satisfactorily reached predetermined and agreed 
milestones and shown its firm commitment to (i) deploy more resources to statistical activities, 
(ii) enhance transparency by fully disclosing background information according to international 
guidelines and standards, and (iii) ensure more independent statistical offices. Where necessary, 
the SCB TA program will also stipulate a clear exit strategy for ADB that will allow ADB to pass 
the funding of most of the statistics budget onto the government of the selected statistically very 
weak DMC, after a specified interval. These conditionalities will help remove common obstacles 
to statistical development.  
 
    b.  Prepare a Monitoring Template 
 
15.  For  each  selected  statistically  very  weak  DMC,  a  monitoring  template  showing  the 
availability of major priority indicators in selected areas will be prepared. Priority will be given to 
those areas of statistics where ADB has considerable experience and some real success in 
providing assistance, namely, poverty statistics, national accounts statistics, price statistics (in 
particular the consumer price index), household and business enterprise surveys, etc. Priority 
consideration will also be given to strengthening MDG indicators. But given the diversity of 
these indicators, only a limited number, including the poverty rate indicator, will be addressed, to 
ensure no loss of focus. The fulfillment of conditionalities will also be included in the template.  
 
                                                 
13 Before this program is developed, it may be necessary to ensure that the selected statistically very weak DMCs 
have a strong commitment to develop their NSS.

5
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total cost of the RETA is estimated to be $600,000. This total includes consulting 
services, country visits, and regional and in-country seminars and workshops. The RETA will be 
financed on a grant basis from ADB’s TA funding program. The detailed cost estimates are 
given in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the RETA. ERD will administer the RETA, with the 
support of an interdepartmental technical working group (TWG) on SCB,14 which will comprise 
staff of ERD and RDs. The group will ensure effective coordination with the concerned RDs. 
 
18.  The study will be implemented over 18 months, from August 2006 to December 2007, 
with the assistance of a team of international and national consultants, to be selected and hired 
individually, according to ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The terms of reference of 
the consultants are in Appendix 3. The results of the first phase of the RETA will be the basis for 
firming up the design and scope of the second phase, which will begin right after phase 1. The 
results thus far of the first phase and approach to diagnostic studies will be discussed at a 
regional  workshop  in  February  2007,  to  be  attended  by  high-level  officials  of  the  DMCs 
concerned, among others. The intent is to secure their commitment to implement the SCB TA 
programs. 
 
19.  The national consultants, in consultation with ADB and under the overall guidance of the 
international consultant, will undertake the country diagnostic studies and develop long-term 
SCB TA programs for the selected statistically very weak DMCs. The national consultants will 
submit  their  reports  within  2  weeks  after  completing  their  assignment.  The  international 
consultant will consolidate all country studies and prepare a draft final report on ADB’s SCB 
program, which will be discussed at the RETA concluding workshop in September 2007. The 
workshop will be attended by senior statisticians of the selected statistically very weak DMCs, 
members  of  the  TWG  on  SCB,  RD  and  resident  mission  staff,  international  and  national 
consultants,  and  resource  persons  from  international  organizations,  among  others.  The 
international consultant will finalize the report, after incorporating the comments of the workshop 
participants, and submit it to ADB by the end of October 2007.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
Statistical Capacity Building in the Asia and Pacific Region, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board. 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.  
                                                 
 
14 The terms of reference of the TWG on SCB include (i) coordinating SCB work between the RDs and ERD, 
(ii) providing advisory services in implementing the new approach to SCB, and (iii) sharing lessons learned by the 
various departments from past SCB TA projects.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE OF CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Statistics Consultant (5 person-months, intermittently) 
1.  The international statistical consultant should have a strong background in statistics or 
economics, extensive practical working experience with statistical offices in developing countries, 
and  sufficient  knowledge  of  statistical  development  in  the  region.  The  consultant  will  provide 
necessary guidance to the national consultants, who will undertake a diagnostic study and a long-
term  statistical  capacity  building  (SCB)  technical  assistance  (TA)  program  for  each  selected 
statistically very weak developing member country (DMC).   
 
2.  In particular, the consultant will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review  indicators  that  have  been  used  to  assess  the  statistical  capabilities  of 
national statistical systems (NSSs), taking into account scoring systems developed 
by other agencies for evaluating the level of statistical development of a country. 
 
(ii)  Using available materials, conduct a desk study to assess the level of statistical 
development of selected DMCs. Where necessary, seek further information through 
e-mail, telephone, or, if necessary, field visits. Also take note of the countries that 
already receive extensive statistical assistance from other funding agencies, the 
availability of data, the history of assistance from funding agencies, and any known 
gaps in data and problems with the quality of data.  
 
(iii)  Identify statistically very weak DMCs on the basis of the assessment. To the extent 
possible, rely on existing comprehensive studies, such as the national strategy for 
the development of statistics.  
 
(iv)  Prepare  a  detailed  and  annotated  outline  to  guide  the  national  consultants  in 
developing diagnostic studies and long-term SCB TA programs, and guide and 
supervise the national consultants as necessary.  
 
(v)  Assist and guide the national consultants in conducting workshops, and provide 
other needed assistance to the regional and national workshops.  
 
(vi)  Review  the  draft  SCB  TA  programs  prepared  by  the  national  consultants, 
consolidate the findings and recommendations, and submit to ADB by the end of 
October 2007 a consolidated report on SCB that includes the comments of the 
workshop participants.  
 
(vii)  Prepare  draft  monitoring  templates  showing  the  availability  of  major  priority 
indicators in selected areas, with inputs from the national consultants. 
 
(viii)  Participate in the regional workshop and the concluding workshop organized by 
ADB. 
 
 
B.  National Statistics Consultants (45 person-months, intermittently) 
3.  The  national  consultants  should  have  a  strong  background  in  statistics  or  economics, 
enough practical knowledge of how the NSSs in the DMCs operate, and working experience with

10  Appendix 3 
 
the  NSSs.  The  consultants  should  also  have  the  expertise  needed  to  assess  the  capacity, 
strengths, and weaknesses of NSSs in the selected statistically very weak DMCs. 
 
4.  Under the overall guidance and supervision of the international consultant, each national 
consultant will 
 
(i)  Conduct a diagnostic study of statistical activities, data availability and gaps, past 
and ongoing funding agency assistance, and priority needs, and identify strengths, 
weaknesses, and obstacles to improvements.  
 
(ii)  Conduct workshops to discuss the findings of the diagnostic study. 
 
(iii)  Submit a report on the findings of the diagnostic study to ADB. 
 
(iv)  Collect and compile necessary information on the history of the statistical system, 
covering budget, IT equipment, personnel, and the availability of various data series.  
 
(v)  Develop a draft long-term SCB TA program for the selected statistically very weak 
DMC, in close consultation with the relevant regional department, national statistical 
authorities, concerned senior government officials, national planners, researchers 
and academicians, and private sector groups. 
 
(vi)  Participate in the regional workshop organized by ADB to discuss the approach to 
diagnostic studies, and in the concluding workshop to discuss the draft long-term 
SCB TA programs.  
 
(vii)  Submit the draft final report to ADB at the end of the engagement.
